10036.title: Volunteer as a Food Educators in NYC Elementary Classrooms- New Trainings in October
10036.org: From Farm to Table d/b/a Spoons Across America

10036.description: Fountain House College Re-Entry helps young adults (18-30), who have withdrawn from schoool because of a mental health issue, to develop the knowledge, skills, and abilities to successfully reach their educational goals. We are looking for tutors to support our students who have recently returned to school, in various subjects, most commonly math (algebra, stats, pre-calc) and English (essay writing). Tutoring sessions take place at our Center in Hell's Kitchen, Mon-Thurs, 10am-6:30pm, and can be at a regular time each week or by appointment. * We are especially in need of tutors who are available before 5pm.* This is a great opportunity for someone interested in pursuing a career in education/tutoring!
10036.title: Math and Writing Tutors needed!

10036.description: BUILD is an innovative, college preparatory program. We use entrepreneurship to ignite the potential of youth from under-resourced communities and propel them to high school, college & career success. Volunteer as a BUILD mentor! BUILD Mentors are placed with a high school student team, coaching them through the process of launching real businesses. This makes school more relevant and fun! Mentors can come from any professional background - sharing your skill-sets with students inspires them to stay on the path to college success. Interested in getting involved but can’t mentor weekly? BUILD has one-off and group volunteer opportunities as well. Please email Miranda Bellizia for additional information. Here are some details on what a mentoring commitment looks like: Location: Manhattan, Brooklyn or the Bronx Time commitment: 1 hour, once a week (M-Th) (Group options available) Session runs: October 2017 - June 2018 1 mentors assigned per team (1:4 mentor to student ratio) Sites are accessible through public transportation Get started! Fill out our online application here: https://www.tfaforms.com/254886 Got questions? Email us at NYCVolunteers@build.org
10036.title: Empower Youth Entrepreneurs. Be a BUILD Mentor!

10036.description: Support the efforts of multiple departments in an award-winning, independently-funded non-profit. The All Stars Project is focused on development through performance. The ASP offers programs that reach over 10,000 inner-city youth in New York City each year, and at our headquarters on 42 nd Street we offer continuing development to people of all ages and backgrounds. Volunteers are needed to support the administration of most of our departments. Administrative volunteers are involved in special events, research, community outreach, volunteer recruitment, marketing and more. Daytime, weeknight evening and weekend hours are available.
10036.title: Volunteer Non-Profit Administration Support

10036.description: Supervisor: Helpline Manager Position Summary: Information and Referral Helpline volunteers will offer information and treatment options to callers and answer basic questions regarding body image and eating disorders in a caring and compassionate manner. This position is a great learning opportunity and involves a minimum of 15 hours of training. Primary Responsibilities: 1. Information and Referral Services: Provide positive, respectful and timely responses regarding eating disorder information requests via incoming phone calls, voicemail messages, emails, forums, instant messages, and social media sites under Helpline responsibility. Ensure the distribution of Helpline information and treatment options in a timely manner that fits the needs of the individual and is presented in a professional manner. Compose general letters of response for information requests. Develop skills related to database management. Increase knowledge and understanding concerning eating disorders and how to appropriately support those affected by them. When deemed appropriate by the Helpline Supervisor, serve as a mentor in the training of newer Helpline volunteers and interns. Contribute to the association’s mission of eliminating eating disorders and body dissatisfaction. 2. Program Duties: Assist Program department staff with ongoing educational and outreach projects. Required Qualifications: High energy, positive attitude, and enthusiasm. Meticulous attention to detail and strong organizational skills. Excellent communication skills and demonstrated ability to provide quality customer service. Strong computer skills, data entry and word-processing ability. Must be dependable and self-motivated. Able to work effectively as an individual and as part of a team. Recovery is important to us here at NEDA. We require that applicants with personal experience who are interested in getting involved with the National Eating Disorders Association have two years of strong recovery due to the intense and triggering nature of this position.
10036.title: Helpline Volunteer/Intern

10036.description: Lar Lubovitch and the Board of Directors are pleased to invite you to join the newly formed Junior Board of the Lar Lubovitch Dance Company. Membership on the Junior Board offers a unique opportunity to personally participate in the organization of this prestigious New York dance company. A short list of the benefits includes the following: -Invitations to special junior board member events throughout the year. -Attendance at private rehearsals with dancers and choreographer. -Access to a backstage experience and a chance to meet the dancers. -Acknowledgement and listed by name in all printed programs. -Priority seating for friends purchasing Gala tickets. -Involvement in the planning and staging of dance events To join the Junior Board, each member undertakes the responsibility of a $250 membership per year plus the commitment of selling 5 Gala tickets to the company’s principal event of the season.
10036.title: Seeking Junior Board Members

10036.description: This area of work is supervised by the Vice President/Education Initiatives and involves a variety of substantive and administrative tasks related to the All Stars Project's public relations, marketing and communications projects and thought leadership projects. For example: Helping to maintain and update project calendars. Helping to coordinate review of written materials for the press, publications and All Stars events, preparing background reports and information packets, assisting in producing thought leadership, press events and conferences. Opportunity to write and edit newsletter itmes, short success stories, case studies and media advisories, do background research for speeches and white papers. Excellent communications skills, including writing, editing, proofreading and phone presentation, as well as strong computer skills, including web research and Microsoft Office is helpful.
10036.title: Communications and Thought  Leadership Initiatives Volunteer

10036.description: UX is a development institution that is forward thinking, free of cost, and open to people of all ages. It is a new crossroads for learning. The whole city is its campus. It takes place at the All Stars Project headquarters on 42nd St. and it also takes place in corporate boadrooms and back stage at Broadway theatres, in your neighborhood and at your school, even in your living room if you want it to. It has no tuition and no grades. We are looking for mature adults of all ages, open-minded thinkers, self-starters with organization and planning skills. Good oral and written communication skills. Administrative skills; including but not limited to: Microsoft Suite & Database management. Willingness to travel throughout N.Y.C.'s five boroughs. Some evening and weekend availability a plus.
10036.title: UX - Volunteer

10036.description: Flamenco Vivo Carlota Santana We believe that the universal spirit of flamenco, a multicultural art form, has the power to build bridges between cultures. Artistic Director Carlota Santana leads this company of energetic dancers and musicians in: powerful performances extensive community outreach Volunteers: Work- Study Program Flamenco Vivo’s Work- Study program provides students with the opportunity to work in exchange for free Flamenco Vivo classes and studio rental. Duties include customer service such as checking-in students, handling cash payments and maintaining student records, as well as general office work such as cleaning, relaying messages and providing basic information to the public. Cleaning or maintenance duties require late and early hours of work. Requirements Applicants must reside in NYC and commit to a minimum of 3 months Proficiency in English (Spanish a plus) Prior experience in customer service a must Excellent organizational skills and the ability to multitask with detailed accuracy in a fast-paced environment Proficiency in a Mac and PC environment with Microsoft Word and Excel Benefits Students working a minimum of 6 hours per week will receive a class card for every 3 hours worked.
10036.title: Flamenco Vivo Work/Study Program

10036.description: Gabrielle L. Kurlander has served as the President and CEO of the All Stars Project, Inc. since 1990. During her tenure, the ASP's annual budget has grown from $200,000 to $7 million, entirely from private funding sources. Today, the ASP serves as a new national model for inner-city youth development, operating in New York City, Newark, Chicago, and San Francisco Bay Area. The Office of the President is currently recruiting volunteers with experience in office management. Executive Assistants are responsible for managing special projects, which will be developed and designed based on the individual's strengths and interests.
10036.title: Producing Assistant

10036.description: Youth Onstage! offers young people, ages 14 to 21, the opportunity to perform in and create plays that have something to say about the world and its future. During its first four years, YO! has produced hip-hop cabarets, poetry snaps, and plays by first-time youth writers. All productions are performance experiments, designed to challenge its performers and audiences to think and feel outside of the box. They tackle difficult social and political issues and create an environment in which contemporary urban youth can express their experiences and perspectives to a diverse audience of adults and youth from New York City and beyond. Young people can get involved in YO! by applying to the free after-school performance training program, an integrated course of intensive performance classes volunteer teachers with pofessional theater training. Theater professionals are needed to teach various improvisation and technical classes during the Fall, Spring, or Summer. The Fall and Spring schedule is a ten week program that meets once a week for 90 minute classes. The Summer program runs four times a week for 60 minute classes. http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=81rqVwzzcbs&feature=channel
10036.title: Youth Onstage Faculty

10036.description: Volunteers are the driving force in all of the All Stars programs. Our volunteers are passionate men and women whose tireless work and contributions have helped us to grow into our role as the new model for inner-city youth development. Currently, there is a need for volunteer managers with writing skills and experience with personnel management. As there are various special projects, an interview (by phone or in person) will determine specific assignments based on best fit.
10036.title: Project Manager

10036.description: The Marketing, Sales and Public Relations Department is seeking various interns to work with and be trained by Gail Peck, the Sales Director of the All Stars, Inc. This department works closely with the Castillo Theater, the dynamic home of cutting- edge improvisational, black, social, political, and avant-garde theater that features the work of playwrights from Germany and Martinique as well as Bed- Stuy and the Bronx. Responsibilities: sending out press releases and inviting the press for shows, database up-keep and entry, making sales calls to theater patrons, internet research to make new connections, PR (putting together lists of PR outlets/magazines), etc.
10036.title: Marketing and Sales Intern/ Volunteer

10036.description: The Office of the President is currently recruiting six interns for Fall 2008. Interns will gain valuable hands- on experience in the non- profit sector and will have the opportunity to work with a variety of community organizers and philanthropists. Responsibilities: track the president's written correspondence, produce Board of Directors' meetings, organize special events, maintain large donor databases/files, answer president's telephone line, etc.
10036.title: Intern for the Office of the President

10036.description: Work with our dynamic Sales and Marketing Director to promote a variety of All Stars productions -- from Hip-Hop Cabarets to avante garde drama to community open houses. Work includes targeting various constituencies through online media and phone outreach. Creative ideas and campaigns are welcomed. Day time hours are best.
10036.title: Volunteer Theatre Sales Support

10036.description: We are looking for professional theatre artists and adults with extensive performance background to work as volunteer teachers and builders of Youth Onstage! The program offers young people, ages 14 to 21, the opportunity to perform on stage in plays that have something to say about the world and its future. Volunteers organize and audition new students each semester, and design and teach classes in all the basic aspects of performance. They work to build a cohesive ensemble, help students become comfortable working together, and encourage them to break out of their habitual behaviors and try out new performances.
10036.title: Volunteer Youth Performance School Teachers

10036.description: The Lar Lubovitch Dance Company is world-renowned. We currently have 14 dedicated members on our Senior Board, and we are now seeking to add 3 or 4 more lovers of dance to our circle of supporters. Prospective board members should have an appreciation of dance and be willing to work with other like-minded professionals, helping the company realize its mission. The commitment of time and money are both very reasonable -- while the emotional and spiritual rewards are enormous. We would be very happy to meet with you and let you see what we are all about. Please contact us at your earliest convenience.
10036.title: Seeking Senior Board Members

10036.description: Looking for caring adults to volunteer to support an innovative performance and development program that involves more than 10,000 young people in New York City each year. In the \"All Stars Talent Show,\" every young person who auditions makes it into the show. Adult and youth volunteers work together to conduct community outreach and help produce auditions, workshops and shows. Our \"Center for Youth Development\" on West 42nd Street is the producing headquarters for these off-site productions, which take place in inner-city communities throughout New York City.
10036.title: Inner-City Youth Talent Show Support Staff

10036.description: Castillo Theatre Production Volunteer - A showplace for the plays of Fred Newman and Heiner Muller, a multicultural home for Black theatre, and a hotbed of theatrical improvisation, Castillo includes people of all ages and backgrounds in its creative life. Embarking on its 32nd season, The award winning Castillo Theater brings socially relevant theatre, dealing with contemporary and historical social issues to the heart of New York's commercial theatre district. Volunteers are needed to support all aspects of the theatre. marketing and sales,set design, costumes, wardrobe, lighting, sound, stage management, box office, house staff,theatre administration, audience development, and much more! Most positions will train. Schedules are varied and flexible; however, for some technical positions in the theatre a stable, reliable schedule is essential. Some evening and weekend availability needed.
10036.title: Castillo Theater Production Volunteer

10031.description: Program Description: West Side Campaign Against Hunger pioneered the customer-choice model and combines emergency food relief services to ensure pantry clients' needs are met. Our Mobile Pantry integrates both these services through partnerships, making sure clients are connected to resources in the communities we are serving, while we deliver pantry services. The Mobile Pantry is a specially designed truck to ensure a customer-choice model, staffed with a Pantry Manager/Driver and Community Resource Counselor. Roles & Responsibilities: Assist MP staff with setup at Partner sites (stocking shelves, setting up tables, organizing equipment) Check-in customers Customer service support (assist customers shopping, crowd control, directing people) Restocking MP Pantry through service delivery Assist MP staff with breakdown of pantry (clean shelves, wipe bins, collect garbage, remove any signs, break down any technology, cooking demo, or other activities)
10031.title: WSCAH Mobile Food Pantry Volunteers Needed

10031.description: Reading Partners needs volunteers like you to provide students in under-resourced elementary schools in your community with the proven, individualized reading support they need to read at grade level by fourth grade. Reading is the foundation for all future learning.The ability to read transforms lives and can empower children to reach their full potential. Research shows that when students can read at grade level by fourth grade, they have a greater opportunity to succeed in school and in life. With your help, we can equip students with the foundational skills they need to read at grade level. Each week, you will meet one-on-one with your student every week to help them develop strong literacy skills and discover a passion for reading. We'll provide a structured curriculum, in-person training, and ongoing support to help your student thrive. Rigorous research has proven that Reading Partners significantly increases reading proficiency. No teaching experience required and anyone over the age of 14 can volunteer. Flexible Monday to Thursday volunteer times between 9am and 5pm. Visit our website at www.readingpartners.org/volunteer to sign up and learn more.
10031.title: Become a reading partner- make a lifelong impact on a child (PS 192 Jacob H. Schiff, Manhattan)

10031.description: We are looking for a writing tutor to support a Writing for Social Science course. You would attend class once a week (either MoWe 12:30PM - 1:45PM). This is a 3-5 hour weekly commitment. you would work with groups of students on their writing, meet with students one-on-one when needed you would do in-class presentations about writing topics tailored around the content students are working on, and for those topics that can't be accommodated in class, you would create videos that students can watch ( Khan Academy style--about 2-4 mins in length using Google Hangouts on Air). You would also create a quiz that would go with that video. We'd be able to track analytics and see how students are performing. About Us: CT is the Colin Powell School’s volunteer tutoring program, and a community organization that provides volunteer tutoring support to programs across Manhattan, Bronx, Brooklyn and Queens. We work with afterschool enrichment programs, housing projects, high schools, adult education programs, and a nano-tech lab. As a tutor, you can work with students between 5-60 years old. No formal tutoring experience necessary. We provide flexible training (days, evenings, weekends; in-person and virtual). As a City Tutor, you can be connected to a mentor from an industry you are interested in who can help you with the job search, with drafting professional documents, and preparing for your next career steps. Commitment: 2-5 hours at one of our partner sites, weekly Requirements: A- or A in subject area you’d like to tutor. Overall GPA above 3.0. Or have graduated with a degree in a social science degree.
10031.title: Be a Writing Embedded Tutor for a Writing for Social Science Course

10031.description: We are looking for a writing tutor to support a Women and Politics course. You would attend class once a week (either Tues or Thurs 2-3:15PM ) and the rest of the work would be done flexibly from your own home. This is about a 3-5 hour commitment a week. The instructor has built a class where: students engage with the material in a low stakes manner (through a Wordpress) that extends the conversation outside of class, provides a foundation for their conversations in class, and gives insight for you, the tutor, on how the students are performing, what writing issues they have, and what workshops you should run You would monitor the blog (by making notes in an excel sheet which has already been created). (Note: students have already been invited to the blog, and an audit of who has access has already been done. We have also completed a survey that helps us better understand who the students are.) You would periodically audit the blog, but week-to-week you'd use it as a source of information about what big picture writing issues the students might be having trouble with. (Our intention is to have the instructor create a rough rubric for you to follow in reviewing the blogs for each week. You don't need to grade anything, or read all the posts. You'd just be getting a general sense of how students are answering and if there is a common pattern of error/misunderstanding that we need to address. Maybe it's around citation, or analysis, or integrating the text, etc.) you would do in-class presentations about writing topics tailored around the content students are working on, and for those topics that can't be accommodated in class, you would create videos that students can watch ( Khan Academy style--about 2-4 mins in length using Google Hangouts on Air). You would also create a quiz that would go with that video. We'd be able to track analytics and see how students are performing. Some students might take you up on one-to-one or study group sessions as well.​ About Us: CT is the Colin Powell School’s volunteer tutoring program, and a community organization that provides volunteer tutoring support to programs across Manhattan, Bronx, Brooklyn and Queens. We work with afterschool enrichment programs, housing projects, high schools, adult education programs, and a nano-tech lab. As a tutor, you can work with students between 5-60 years old. No formal tutoring experience necessary. We provide flexible training (days, evenings, weekends; in-person and virtual). As a City Tutor, you can be connected to a mentor from an industry you are interested in who can help you with the job search, with drafting professional documents, and preparing for your next career steps. Commitment: 2-5 hours at one of our partner sites, weekly Requirements: A- or A in subject area you’d like to tutor. Overall GPA above 3.0. Or have graduated with a degree in sociology or related fields.
10031.title: Be an Embedded Writing Tutor: Help Make a Women and Politics Course Student-Centered

10031.description: We are looking for a writing tutor to support an Intro to Political Ideas course. You would attend class once a week (either Tues or Thurs 9:30AM to 10:40AM) and the rest of the work would be done flexibly from your own home. This is about a 3-5 hour commitment a week. We are looking to create an academic support model for jumbo courses that we can apply across disciplines. The instructor has structured the course in a way that accommodates the tutor: students engage with the material in a low stakes manner that extends the conversation outside of class, provides a foundation for their conversations in class, and gives insight for you, the tutor, on how the students are performing, what writing issues they have, and what workshops you should run You would monitor the digital forum (by making notes in an excel sheet which has already been created). Commitment: 2-5 hours at one of our partner sites, weekly Requirements: A- or A in subject area you’d like to tutor. Overall GPA above 3.0. Or have graduated with a degree in political science or related fields.
10031.title: Be an Embedded Writing Tutor: Help Make a Lecture Intro to Political Ideas  Course Student-Centered

10031.title: Be an Embedded Writing Tutor: Help Make a Lecture Sized Intro to Sociology Course Student-Centered

10031.description: City Tutors ( thecitytutors.com ) is looking for mentors to support our tutors. If you are interested in helping someone who is actively engaged in building their leadership skills and making an impact on their community, apply through our website or send your resume directly to thenycitytutors@gmail.com Commitment: Mentors commit to speaking with tutors over video or phone a minimum of once a month, and meeting with them a minimum of every 8 weeks. Mentors are provided training as part of the onboarding process. Training is about 30 mins to 1 hour. Requirements: Must have received at least a bachelors degree and have 2+ years of professional experience. Here's a video about our mentorship program: https://lnkd.in/en7hHnX About Us: CT is the Colin Powell School’s volunteer tutoring program, and a community organization that provides volunteer tutoring support to programs across Manhattan, Bronx, Brooklyn and Queens. We work with afterschool enrichment programs, housing projects, high schools, adult education programs, and a nano-tech lab. As a tutor, you can work with students between 5-60 years old.
10031.title: Mentor a College Student/Young Professional Impacting Positively the Community

10031.description: 1. Regularly attends board meetings and important related meetings. 2. Makes serious commitment to participate actively in committee work. 3. Volunteers for and willingly accepts assignments and completes them thoroughly and on time. 4. Stays informed about committee matters, prepares themselves well for meetings, and reviews and comments on minutes and reports. 5. Gets to know other committee members and builds a collegial working relationship that contributes to consensus. 6. Is an active participant in the committee's annual evaluation and planning efforts. 7. Participates in fund raising for the organization .
10031.title: Board Member Wanted

10031.description: This is a 7-14 hour internship. At least one day requires your physical presence in the office. Some of the work can be done off site. The position will run to the summer. Role will require you to: Create a strategic plan for promoting City Tutors at CCNY Support the CCNY CT executive board as it identifies and interviews candidates for positions on its extended team focused on outreach on and off campus Identify candidates for e-board teams at other CUNY campuses we are partnered with Identify people and places we should connect with to recruit tutors/mentors Collaborate with graphic designer, videographer, and UX designer to create material that will help us better connect with a variety of stakeholders.
10031.title: Marketing Manager Intern

10031.description: The City Tutors (CT) is looking for an embedded (in-class) writing tutor to provide academic support for an Introduction to Anthropology course at the City College of New York. The class meets Mondays and Wednesdays from 5:00 pm - 6:15 pm. This is a great opportunity for someone who is interested in tutoring, or who is majoring (or has already earned a degree) in the course area to enhance their knowledge and experience. In this role, you would collaborate with an instructor to improve students’ performance while being supported and guided by an experienced academic support professional. All embedded tutors for the Introduction to Anthropology course are expected to commit a minimum of one hour and fifteen minutes class session per week, and two hours availability outside of class to support students having difficulty with the material. You would identify and support students who are struggling, participate during the lecture to augment the class topic discussions, moderate an online forum to assist student's understanding of the material, and provide feedback to the instructor regarding students' concerns and difficulties that can lead to changes in future lessons. You might also design assignments, identify/track students who are struggling, and create differentiated instruction as the need arises. You will be supported throughout this process by the City Tutors staff. All tutors are also expected to complete a four session comprehensive, professional training regimen. 6 hours of live training, plus another hour and a half for orientation. This is a commitment of 7.5 hours of in person training, and 4 hours of supplemental training for a total of 11.5 hours of training over the course of the Fall semester. Training days will be determined based on your schedule and that of the Tutor Training Coordinators. CT's embedded tutoring program has been successful in helping students gain access to support that they otherwise would not have received, given their limited time spent on campus. Having a tutor in the class early in the semester will allow us to employ strategies to reduce withdrawals and student failure rates. Your work with us would help the students’ overall subject area performance, and help us improve this educational support model, reaching more students and departments with comprehensive academic support. To apply, you must: Have received an A- or A in writing courses Have a GPA at or above 3.2, or have completed a degree program Submit monthly reports, keep a log sheet of any tutoring appointments done outside of class, and regularly communicate with the tutor training coordinator.
10031.title: In-Class Tutor Needed For Introduction to Anthropology Honors Course for Fall 2017 Semester

10031.description: The Boys and Girls Club of Harlem works with young adults and kids throughout the Harlem area. We ensure students have a safe place to learn and grow into functioning members of society. BGCH is seeking an administrative support volunteer to help organize our classrooms and files, provide frontline assistance, and other administrative tasks that may arise. Our schedule is flexible and we can work around your schedule. Volunteer support allows BGCH to help more kids with a better environment to learn.
10031.title: Administrative Support

10031.description: Mentors: Schedule-Varies depending on program The Boys and Girls Club of Harlem is seeking professionals interested in doing group mentoring with our Teens. We operate several programs during the school year designed to encourage our female teen members a safe place to discuss their social, health, and mental needs. Our teen program for males provides them the opportunity to become more well-rounded individuals capable of making better choices. Our volunteers should be willing to listen and understand what teen members are saying. Volunteers should also be prepared to share their own personal experiences that can make teens feel more secure. There is also an expectation that volunteers will agree to consistently show up to group mentoring events. This provides them the opportunity to see an adult on a regular basis. Schedule:The program begins September 28th and runs until December 21st. Every Thursday from 5pm-7pm. Passport to Manhood: Passport to manhood works with our male club members between the ages of 11-17. It is a 14 session program that concentrates on specific aspects of manhood through interactive activities. The program addresses critical issues that young men face during their teen and young adult lives. Passport to Manhood discusses good ethics, decision-making, wellness, ideas about fatherhood, employment and careers, cooperation and conflict,diversity, relationships and self esteem. Smart Girls: Smart girls helps develop and adopt healthy attitude and lifestyle, as well as, acquire and maintain positive self-concept, sound decision-making skills and mentor relationships. Female club members between 11-17 years old navigate their way through this program that gives them the tools to make good health and social decisions.
10031.title: Group Mentoring

10031.description: The volunteer would assist with IBREA FOUNDATION;s project in A. Philip Randolph High school. He/she will help with preparing materials, distributing materials, room set up (projector, music, handouts, mats etc), helping kids focus (silencing them, seeing if there are any individual concerns etc), administration (taking attendance, inputing attendance, reading journals, organizing pictures etc).
10031.title: Volunteer for holistic education project in Harlem

10031.description: City Tutors (CT), the tutoring arm of the Colin Powell School, is currently looking for two tutors to provide academic support for students in Intermediate Micro and Macroeconomics courses. Tutors for the Intermediate Economics courses will serve in the role of study group leaders. In this role, you would take the lead to improve students’ performance while being supported and guided by CT coordinators. All majors are welcome to apply. This is a great opportunity especially for Economics/Business Management/Finance majors or minors. You should consider applying if you are interested in building professional contacts with faculty and staff at the Colin Powell School who can later speak to your professional capability at the cross section of your academic interests, would like to help your peers and make an impact on students' classroom learning experience, and if you are interested in exploring your academic interest area at the cross section of education. If you are applying for the study group leader position supporting the Intermediate Economics courses, you need to have taken the same intermediate economics course you wish to tutor, received A- or A in that economics course, have an overall GPA at 3.2 or higher All City Tutors are expected to complete a four session comprehensive, professional training regimen. 6 hours of live training, plus another hour and a half for orientation. This is a commitment of 7.5 hours of in person training, and 4 hours of supplemental training for a total of 11.5 hours of training over the course of the Fall semester. If you are unable to attend the regular training sessions, you will need to attend makeup sessions. The dates for these sessions will be determined based on your schedule and that of the Tutor Training Coordinator’s. Learn more about the City Tutors here: thecitytutors.com The City Tutors (CT) was founded at The City College of New York with the premise that a volunteer tutoring program working collaboratively with educational partners can help improve retention and graduation rates.
10031.title: Spring 2018 Seeking Volunteer Tutors to Support Courses in Intermediate Micro and/or Macro Economics

10031.description: The City Tutors (CT) is looking for a tutor to run study groups that provide academic support for CCNY Biology 102 class students for the Spring 2018 Semester. Biology 102 is an introductory course for science students. Classes in the Fall met twice a week on Mondays and Wednesdays from 3:30pm to 4:45pm, though this schedule may change for the Spring 2018 semester. This is a great opportunity for students who are majoring (or have already earned a degree) in the course area to enhance their knowledge and experience, and for those who are interested in tutoring in their subject area of interest. In this role, you will be in communication with an instructor to improve students’ performance. Throughout this process, you will be supported and guided by an experienced academic support professional. A tutor supporting this Biology 102 class is expected to commit a minimum of three hours and thirty minutes every week. You will need to attend both the Monday and Wednesday classes (assuming schedule remains unchanged), as well as provide a minimum of one hour study group support. Study group times will be determined from a survey done in class asking when students will be available for sessions. Times that fit with the majority of students and the tutor will be selected for study groups. You would identify and support students who are struggling, and provide feedback to the instructor regarding students' concerns and difficulties that can lead to changes in future lessons. You will also meet with the CCNY Biology Department staff. You will be supported throughout this process by the City Tutors staff. All tutors are expected to complete 6 hours of live training, plus another hour and a half for orientation. This is a commitment of 7.5 hours of in person training, and 4 hours of supplemental training for a total of 11.5 hours of training over the course of the Fall semester. CT's tutoring program has been successful in helping students gain access to support that they otherwise would not have received, given their limited time spent on campus. Having a tutor support class early in the semester will allow us to employ strategies to reduce withdrawals and student failure rates. Your work with us would help the students’ overall subject area performance, and help us improve this educational support model, reaching more students and departments with comprehensive academic support. Learn more about CCNY Biology Department here: https://www.ccny.cuny.edu/biology To apply, you must: Have received an A- or A in the introduction to the subject course you are applying to tutor Have a GPA at or above 3.2, or have completed a degree program receiving higher than a 3.0 Make monthly meetings, keep a log sheet of any tutoring appointments done outside of class, and regularly communicate with the tutor training coordinator.
10031.title: Spring 2018 Biology Tutor needed for Bio 102 course held through the CCNY Biology Department

You would identify and support students who are struggling, participate during the lecture to augment the class topic discussions, and provide feedback to the instructor regarding students' concerns and difficulties that can lead to changes in future lessons. You might also design assignments, identify/track students who are struggling and create differentiated instruction as the need arises. You will be supported throughout this process by the City Tutors staff. All embedded tutors are also expected to complete a four session comprehensive professional training regimen. Training days will be determined based on your schedule and that of the Tutor Training Coordinators. CT's embedded tutoring program has been successful in helping students gain access to support that they otherwise would not have received, given their limited time spent on campus. Having a tutor in the class early in the semester will allow us to employ strategies to reduce withdrawals and student failure rates. Your work with us would help the students’ overall subject area performance, and help us improve this educational support model, reaching more students and departments with comprehensive academic support. Learn more about College Now here: https://www.ccny.cuny.edu/collegenow To apply, you must: Have received an A- or A in the introduction to the subject course you are applying to tutor Have a GPA at or above 3.2, or have completed a degree program Submit monthly reports, keep a log sheet of any tutoring appointments done outside of class, and regularly communicate with the tutor training coordinator.

10030.description: Future Giants is a non profit that has operated in NYC for over 11 years. We specialize in preparing High School students for the social and academic challenges they will encounter after graduation. We have a 100 college acceptance rate and a 99 % on time High School Graduation rate. Last year we created and published a High school book that is being used in several High Schools. We are seeking Volunteers that have a direct or indirect contact with the Mayors of Baltimore and or D.C. It is our hope to recreate our success in those cities as well as open our first multi organization youth center (A.C.E) Future Giants is planning to Launch our Academic + Community = Excellence If you have any contacts with the Mayors of either Baltimore ,MD or D.C ( or the Governor) we would like your assistance in helping thousands of young people achieve their dreams.
10030.title: Reference to Mayor of D.C. and or Baltimore

10030.description: Reading Partners needs volunteers like you to provide students in under-resourced elementary schools in your community with the proven, individualized reading support they need to read at grade level by fourth grade. Reading is the foundation for all future learning.The ability to read transforms lives and can empower children to reach their full potential. Research shows that when students can read at grade level by fourth grade, they have a greater opportunity to succeed in school and in life. With your help, we can equip students with the foundational skills they need to read at grade level. Each week, you will meet one-on-one with your student every week to help them develop strong literacy skills and discover a passion for reading. We'll provide a structured curriculum, in-person training, and ongoing support to help your student thrive. Rigorous research has proven that Reading Partners significantly increases reading proficiency. No teaching experience required and anyone over the age of 14 can volunteer. Flexible Monday to Thursday volunteer times between 9am and 5pm. Visit our website at www.readingpartners.org/volunteer to sign up and learn more.
10030.title: Become a reading partner- make a lifelong impact on a child (PS 123, Manhattan)

10030.description: The Administrative volunteer will provide clerical support to the Executive Assistant in helping Iris House to accomplish their mission. Iris House saves lives through comprehensive support, prevention and education services for women, families, and underserved populations affected by HIV/AIDS and other health disparities in a safe, family-centered environment by passionate, professional and culturally competent staff.
10030.title: Help Your Community!

10030.description: Join the volunteer team at Behind the Book (www.behindthebook.org), a non-profit literacy organization that inspires New York City public school students to love reading. We bring accomplished authors into pre-K-12 classrooms in high-needs schools, where they teach a genre of writing and guide students in creating their own writing projects, based on the theme of the author's book. Our rich, innovative programs, which are part of the class curricula and meet Common Core Learning Standards, have a successful record of building literacy skills and creating motivated readers at schools around the city. You need no experience or training to volunteer as a classroom coach to engage and encourage students as they work. You'll help small groups of students edit short stories or essays, research a topic, or create artwork to illustrate their writing. Individual workshops run 1 to 2 hours on a school day, usually in the morning. You can participate in any number of workshops in a program, which run for 3 to 6 dates scheduled over a few weeks. With a fresh slate creative, thought-provoking programs every school year, you'll find many workshops you'll want to be part of. For information on current progaams that need your support, please visit http://www.behindthebook.org/current-volunteer-opportunities/ To join our team and receive announcements of new volunteer opportunities, please complete our brief questionnaire at http://www.behindthebook.org/join-us/volunteer/
10030.title: Classroom Volunteer/Writing Coach

10033.description: Food pantry volunteers are needed in Washington Heights. The pantry is open Tuesday, Wednesday, and Thursday. This client choice food pantry serves New Yorkers in need. 10111.description: The National MS Society is looking for volunteers to cheer on participants at Climb to the Top NYC! Climb to the Top NYC 2018 will be held on Sunday, March 4th at Rockefeller Center in Manhattan. We welcome groups and individuals of all ages & abilities to join us as volunteers! This is a unique event that the New York City - Southern New York market of the National MS Society hosts to raise awareness and funds for the 12,000 people living with MS that we serve in the five boroughs and Westchester, Putnam, Rockland, Orange and Sullivan counties. More than 300 volunteers are needed to make this event a success. If you are interested in volunteering, please review the position below and register online here: www.climbMSnyc.org Volunteer Check-In Team Date: Sunday, March 4 Location: Rockefeller Center Time: 4:30am-10:00am Description: Volunteers will check-in volunteers and direct them to assigned locations. If you have any questions, please contact: Amber Young - Manager, Volunteer Engagement at Amber.Young@nmss.org or 212-453-3258

10034.description: The City Tutors (CT) is looking for tutors to provide embedded (in-class) academic support in ESL for the CUNY in the Heights in two sections this fall. One class meets Tuesday/Thursday evenings from 6-9pm, and consists of low/intermediate English Language Learners. A second class meets on Saturdays from 10:00 am - 2:00 pm, and works with basic ESL learners. This is a great opportunity for students who are majoring (or have already earned a degree) in the course area to enhance their knowledge and experience and who are interested in tutoring. In this role, you would collaborate with an instructor to improve students’ performance while being supported and guided by an experienced academic support professional. The tutor for CUNY in the Heights is expected to commit a minimum of two hours to support one of the above-mentioned days. You would identify and support students who are struggling, and provide feedback to students so that they may improve their fundamental understanding of the material. You might also design assignments, identify/track students who are struggling and create differentiated instruction as the need arises. You will be supported throughout this process by the City Tutors staff. All tutors are also expected to complete a four session comprehensive, professional training regimen. 6 hours of live training, plus another hour and a half for orientation. This is a commitment of 7.5 hours of in person training, and 4 hours of supplemental training for a total of 11.5 hours of training over the course of the Fall semester. Training days will be determined based on your schedule and that of the Tutor Training Coordinators. CT's tutoring program has been successful in helping students gain access to support that they otherwise would not have received, given their limited time spent on campus. Having a tutor in the class early in the semester will allow us to employ strategies to reduce withdrawals and student failure rates. Your work with us would help the students’ overall subject area performance, and help us improve this educational support model, reaching more students and departments with comprehensive academic support. 10034.title: ESL Tutor Needed to Provide Embedded (In-Class) Support at CUNY in the Heights

10034.description: The City Tutors (CT) is looking for tutors to provided embedded (in-class) academic support in ESL for students at the CUNY in the Heights this fall. The class meets on Saturdays from 10:00 am - 12:00 pm, and tutors with work with basic level learners in the class. This is a great opportunity for students who are majoring (or have already earned a degree) in the course area to enhance their knowledge and experience and who are interested in tutoring. In this role, you would collaborate with an instructor to improve students’ performance while being supported and guided by an experienced academic support professional. The tutor for CUNY in the Heights is expected to commit a minimum of two hours to support the class on Saturday. You would identify and support students who are struggling, and provide feedback to students so that they may improve their fundamental understanding of the material. You might also design assignments, identify/track students who are struggling and create differentiated instruction as the need arises. You will be supported throughout this process by the City Tutors staff. All tutors are also expected to complete a four session comprehensive, professional training regimen. 6 hours of live training, plus another hour and a half for orientation. This is a commitment of 7.5 hours of in person training, and 4 hours of supplemental training for a total of 11.5 hours of training over the course of the Fall semester. Training days will be determined based on your schedule and that of the Tutor Training Coordinators. CT's tutoring program has been successful in helping students gain access to support that they otherwise would not have received, given their limited time spent on campus. Having a tutor in the class early in the semester will allow us to employ strategies to reduce withdrawals and student failure rates. Your work with us would help the students’ overall subject area performance, and help us improve this educational support model, reaching more students and departments with comprehensive academic support. 10006.description: Position: Administrative Volunteer Reports To: Director of Outreach Location: 65 Broadway New York, NY, 10006 General Purpose: The Administrative Volunteer serves as a representative for PSS Circle of Care, supporting the Agency's mission of strengthening the capacity of older New Yorkers, their families, and communities to thrive. Key Responsibilities: The Volunteer enters information into computer databases for effective record keeping Organizing files and collecting data to be entered into the computer Time Commitment: Two days per week (M/W or T/Th), 10a-4p) Support: Training for this position will be provided. Also, the Director of Outreach will be available for questions and assistance. Dress Code: Business Casual Start Date: Immediate Required Qualifications/Skills: Basic knowledge of computer and data entry. Pleasant manner, patience, and, dependability. Fluent Spanish speaker preferred. Benefits: Volunteers will work with a diverse range of people and have the opportunity to showcase their skills by engaging with senior members and supporting staff. In addition, volunteers will have chance to network, grow as an individual and build their resume.
10006.title: Administrative Volunteer

10006.description: Position: Outreach Volunteer Reports To: Director of Outreach Location: 65 Broadway New York, NY, 10006 General Purpose: The Outreach Volunteer serves as a representative for PSS Circle of Care, supporting the Agency's mission of strengthening the capacity of older New Yorkers, their families, and communities to thrive. Key Responsibilities: The Outreach Volunteer will represent PSS at health fairs, hand out promotional material to health fair attendees and inform them of PSS’ services Answers questions about the agency and provides forms when necessary Time Commitment: Should be flexible. Preferably 2 days per week (M, W, or F) for five hours (9-2 am and 12-5 pm) or dependent on the time of the event. Support: Training for this position will be provided. Also, the Director of Outreach will be available for questions and assistance. Dress Code: Business Casual Start Date: Immediate Required Qualifications/Skills: Must present an outgoing nature, highly professional appearance, and articulate. Fluent Spanish speaker preferred. Benefits: Volunteers will work with a diverse range of people and have the opportunity to showcase their skills by engaging with senior members and supporting staff. In addition, volunteers will have chance to network, grow as an individual and build their resume.
10006.title: Outreach Volunteer

10006.description: MJHS Hospice provides a specialized program of care and services for end-of-life patients. MJHS Hospice provides care for pediatric and adult patients in homes, nursing homes, assisted living communities, inpatient facilities and hospitals. MJHS Hospice Volunteer opportunities include: Providing support and companionship to patients and their families Participating in leisure activities such as reading, listening to music, playing games with patients Supporting or organizing group activities for patients Listening compassionately to patients and their families Providing office or clerical support for our hospice team Complementary therapies Requirements for all categories of volunteers: 18 years or older 15 hours of training (4 hours training for clerical/office volunteers) Background Check (no charge to applicant) Medical Clearance (no charge to applicant) 3-4 hours per week 1 year commitment Required skills for patient visits: discretion, patience, compassion and dedication Preferred clerical and office support skills include: receptionist skills, computer skills, organizational skills and filing For more information on how to become a MJHS Hospice Volunteer please call: Mical White-Huffstead, Coordinator of Volunteer Servies; 718-490-1900 or mhuffste@mjhs.org Denise Jones, Coordinator of Volunteer Services; 347-633-3421 or dejones@mjhs.org Tiara Moultrie, Coordinator of Volunteer Services; (212)-649-5515 or tmoultri@mjhs.org Ivi Wakneen, Coordinator of Volunteer Services; (212)-649-5264 or iwakneen@mjhs.org
10006.title: Be Part of Someone's Legacy--Become a Hospice Volunteer!

10006.description: Position: Social Media Volunteer Reports To: PSS Communications Manager Location: Administrative Office General Purpose: The Social Media Volunteer serves as a representative for PSS, supporting the Agency's mission of strengthening the capacity of older New Yorkers, their families, and communities to thrive. Key Responsibilities: Build and execute social media strategy through research, messaging and audience identification Generate, edit, publish and share daily content (original text, images, video or HTML) that builds meaningful connections and encourages community members to take action Set up and optimize company pages within each platform to increase the visibility of company’s social content Moderate all user-generated content in line with the moderation policy for each community Expectations: Must be punctual and have consistent attendance, Be prepared to work as part of a team, Time commitment of 5-10 hours a week (flexible and possibly virtual) Qualifications/Skills: Team player, Comfortable interacting with Seniors, Bilingual in English and Spanish (preferred), Friendly Attitude Time Commitment: Minimum 5-10 hours a week (flexible, possibly virtual) Support: Training for this position will be provided. Age Requirement: None Dress Code: Casual Start Date: Immediate Required Qualifications/Skills: Proven working experience in social media or related field Excellent writing, editing (photo/video/text), presentation and communication skills Demonstrable social networking experience and social analytics tools knowledge Positive attitude, volunteer spirit and good multitasking abilities Benefits: Volunteers will work with a diverse range of people and have the opportunity to showcase their skills by engaging with senior members and supporting staff. In addition, volunteers will have chance to network, grow as an individual and build their resume.
10006.title: Social Media Outreach Volunteer

10006.description: New York Cares offers many programs serving adults and children with special needs. Our volunteers provide a little extra care and attention to the physically disabled, who often face limited recreational activities and educational opportunities. These projects provide important social interaction while teaching essential independent living skills. Search our projects at www.newyorkcares.org/search/project Before you can volunteer on a New York Cares project, you must attend a one-hour orientation. After that, you can choose from hundreds of flexibly scheduled volunteer projects every month. Learn more about volunteering with New York Cares at www.newyorkcares.org.
10006.title: Adults and Children with Special Needs Projects with New York Cares

10006.description: Planning for a better future starts by believing that one is possible. On New York Cares' Adult Education projects, volunteers help capable but struggling New Yorkers, many of whom are transitioning out of homelessness, build a brighter future for themselves and their families. Search our projects at www.newyorkcares.org/search/project Before you can volunteer on a New York Cares project, you must attend a one-hour orientation. After that, you can choose from hundreds of flexibly scheduled volunteer projects every month. Learn more about volunteering with New York Cares at www.newyorkcares.org.
10006.title: Adult Education and Job Readiness Projects with New York Cares

10032.description: The City Tutors (CT) is looking for tutors to provide academic support in Middle School/High School reading and writing for the Sugar Hill Project’s Teen’s Homework Club this fall. Sessions meet three times each week on Mondays, Tuesdays, and Wednesdays. The sessions run from 3:00 - 5:30 PM. This is a great opportunity for students who are majoring (or have already earned a degree) in the course area to enhance their knowledge and experience and who are interested in tutoring. In this role, you would take the lead to improve students’ performance while being supported and guided by City Tutor’s coordinators. The tutor for Sugar Hill Project’s Homework club is expected to commit a minimum of an hour and a half to support one of the above-mentioned days. You would identify and support students who are struggling, and provide feedback to students so that they may improve their fundamental understanding of the material. You might also design assignments, identify/track students who are struggling and create differentiated instruction as the need arises. You will be supported throughout this process by the City Tutors staff. All tutors are also expected to complete a four session comprehensive, professional training regimen. 6 hours of live training, plus another hour and a half for orientation. This is a commitment of 7.5 hours of in person training, and 4 hours of supplemental training for a total of 11.5 hours of training over the course of the Fall semester. Training days will be determined based on your schedule and that of the Tutor Training Coordinators. CT's tutoring program has been successful in helping students gain access to support that they otherwise would not have received, given their limited time spent on campus. Having tutors in these sessions early in the semester will allow us to employ strategies to reduce withdrawals and student failure rates. Your work with us would help the students’ overall subject area performance, and help us improve this educational support model, reaching more students and departments with comprehensive academic support. Learn more about Sugar Hill Project here: http://www.bhc.org/sugarhill/ To apply, you must: Have received an A- or A in the introduction to the subject course you are applying to tutor Have a GPA at or above 3.2, or have completed a degree program Submit monthly reports, keep a log sheet of any tutoring appointments done outside of class, and regularly communicate with the tutor training coordinator.

10032.description: The City Tutors (CT) provides in-class academic support for a 9th grade algebra class (a total of little more than 30 students) at Community Health Academy High School (located a block away from the 157th stop on the 1 train). The teacher has really enjoyed working with City Tutors, and we would like to continue to support her course in Spring 2018. The times of the classes are to be determined. This is a great opportunity for individuals who have a strong foundation in the material, and are interested in gaining practical experience working in the classroom. As an embedded tutor, you will collaborate with an instructor to improve students’ performance, while being supported and guided by an experienced academic support professional. All embedded tutors commit three hours for the week. You will sit in on the class, and sometimes provide tutoring support after class (or on a different day if that's more agreeable) depending on students’ availability and interest. You will speak with the instructor weekly to prep for the next class and debrief after the Wed session. You would identify and support students who are struggling and provide feedback to the instructor regarding students' concerns and difficulties that can lead to changes in future lessons. You might also design assignments, identify/track students who are struggling and create differentiated instruction as the need arises. CT's embedded tutoring program has been successful in helping students gain access to support that they otherwise would not have received. Your work with us would help the students’ overall subject area performance, and help us improve this educational support model at the site. To apply, you must: Have received an A- or A in the introduction to the subject course you are applying to tutor. Have a GPA at or above 3.2, or have received a degree recently. Be willing to complete 11.5 hours of College Reading and Learning Aligned (CRLA) training at City College of New York. We can accommodate your schedule for the training sessions.
10032.title: Spring 2018 In-Class Tutoring Support for a 9th Grade Algebra Class

10032.description: Morgan Stanley Children’s Hospital of NewYork-Presbyterian is currently seeking volunteers for our Family Resource Center (FRC). The FRC is open Monday through Friday from 10 a.m. to 6 p.m. Volunteers are crucial to our mission of providing high quality patient-centered care to patients and families. We are seeking volunteers throughout the day and on some evenings. Interested candidates may apply at www.nyp.org/volunteer. The Center is a great place for families to relax, a place to get away from the bedside for a brief time and very importantly, to get assistance with obtaining reliable medical information pertaining to their hospitalized or out-patient family member. We have four computer workstations and a business center that families use to fax documents, scan to e-mail and copy health related materials for reading or sharing. Additionally, we have a growing reference library and recreational reading material. Volunteers assist with welcoming families and assisting them in using the computers, giving directions, visiting the units to distribute books and other materials and assisting the Health Librarian and Administrative Assistant with various clerical duties as well as with projects that we are working on. We look forward to hearing from you! Best, Volunteer Services
10032.title: Morgan Stanley Children's Hospital Family Resource Center
